message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of multiple, nontender, round, white macules on the chest and trunk with fine scaling when scraped with a spatula suggest pityriasis versicolor. This is typically caused by the overgrowth of Malassezia globosa, a type of yeast that is a normal part of the skin flora. The other options do not fit with the patient’s history and symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The white macules with fine scaling suggest tinea versicolor, which is caused by increased growth of Malassezia globosa. The other options are not associated with this specific presentation.

All other options are not consistent with the symptoms presented.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location and description of the rash suggests tinea versicolor, which is caused by Malassezia globosa, a fungus that commonly lives on the skin. Autoimmune destruction of melanocytes causes vitiligo, which presents as depigmented macules. Increased sebum production is associated with acne vulgaris. Exposure to human herpes virus 7 can cause roseola.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including the location and appearance of the rash, are consistent with pityriasis versicolor, which is caused by an overgrowth of the yeast Malassezia globosa. Autoimmune destruction of melanocytes is associated with vitiligo, which presents with depigmented macules or patches. Increased sebum production is associated with acne, which presents with papules, pustules, and comedones. Exposure to human herpes virus 7 is associated with roseola, which presents with fever and a rash that starts on the trunk and spreads to the limbs.

The other options are not associated with this type of rash.
